bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 25, 1947

div1.p: Moran discusses Cuban politics in general. He notes that the Finlay-Reed controversy is still ongoing, and there are strong anti-American sentiments connected with it.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 25, 1947
div1.opener:
JOHN J. MORAN
HAVANA, CUBA
June 25, 1947.
Gen. Jefferson R. Kean,
U. S. Army - Retired,
Washington, D. C.
Dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I am most grateful to you for your six-page letter of
May 25th, repeating what you wrote to me back in 1939. I was
foolish enough to relinquish that letter to the secretary of the
Rotary Club, for translation, with the express condition that it
be returned to me. As frequently happens elsewhere, but always
in Cuba, some people are not very scrupolous in matters of that
nature. The good intentions may be there at the moment, only to
be immediately forgotten. I could never get your original letter
back, so that I could not even make a copy of it. Your letter, I
well recall, was translated in “running” fashion by a Cuban who
was well versed in English. After your letter was read, the
next speaker at the lunch was our old friend and enemy, Dr.
Francisco Dominguez Roldan, the self-appointed champion of Finlay
and author (in French) of Finlay's biography. Your clear and
concise statements made no impression on him. He went on to claim
all the glory for Finlay. I regret to record that ALL Cuban
medicos want to see eye to eye with the late Finlay biographer.
That work was a sad travesty on historical accuracy and truth.
It had a limited circulation in France, just enough to confuse
French scientific opinion and cloud Reed's accomplishment. To add
to the confusion, Dr. Juan Guiteras, who knew all the facts, later
on claimed all the glory for Finlay. Due to his enmity towards
General Crowder, American Ambassador during the Zayas regime, he
became violently anti-American. As Secretary of Sanitation, he
incurred the displeasure of General Crowder through his lack of
cooperation with the Public Health Service of the U. S. in matters
of quarantine. He had exaggerated views on the sovereign rights
of Cuba in quarantine matters, holding that Cuban sanitation was
superior to that of the U. S. He wanted no suggestions from the
U. S. in his department. Without shadow of a doubt, he was a real
Cuban patriot but he ignored the part played by the U. S. in making
Cuba a health resort. The upshot of it all was his removal from
the “Honest Cabinet” which Zayas was obliged to name by Crowder.
Once Zayas got the $50,000,000 loan for Cuba from the U. S., he
promptly disposed, one by one, of Crowder's HONEST CABINET. He
put one over on Crowder and flagrantly violated his word of honor
to the effect that he would stick to the Honest Cabinet.

You are entirely correct in assuming that your letter to
Dr. Noguera will not change his attitude in the Reed-Finlay matter.
By the way, he is no longer Director of Public Health. His resign-
ation was called for a few weeks after his return to Cuba. Since
my letter to you was xxx not sealed when I handed it to him, I could
not well tell you this. You cannot convince a man who does not
have an open mind and when it comes to the Reed-Finlay matter I do
not know of but one Cuban doctor who did have an open mind. That
man was the late Dr. Albertini, one of the signers of my yellow
JOHN J. MORAN
HAVANA, CUBA
General Jefferson R. Kean.
-- 2 --
June 25, 1947.
fever certificate and the junior member of the Yellow Fever Board
of the City of Havana, of which Dr. Finlay was President, with
Gorgas and Guiteras. He admitted to me personally, several years
ago, that it would be equivalent to suicide for him or any other
Cuban medico to combat the FINLAY ONLY school, headed by Dr. Francisco
Dominguez Roldan. At that time, Dr. Albertini was director of the
Instituto Finlay. This clique of Cuban medicos got to work on
Dr. Juan Guiteras, Dr. Aristides Agramonte and others, with the
result that they all finally considered it the better part of wisdom
to fall in line. The younger generation of Cuban medicos have
learned their lesson so well that it would be “Love's Labor Lost”
to try to convince them that THE CONQUEST OF YELLOW FEVER was a
REED-FINLAY accomplishment. I reckon that you and I are the only
living witnesses of actually what happened in Cuba in the last six
months of 1900 and the first two months of the 20th Century - in
the Yellow Fever field. It is regrettable that you never wrote
the story. General Truby, I regret to state, deals too much with
Truby and too little with Reed, in his book. You could have done
a much better job of it. Please do not think I am prejudiced
against General Truby. I have nothing against him. I remember
him best as a chubby-faced “shave-tail”. At Columbia Barracks
Post Hospital I reported directly to Major Stark whom I assisted in
the operating room. There were but two regular army medicos, viz:
Stark, with temporary rank of Major and Truby, 1st Lieutenant &
Asst. Surgeon. All the rest of them were Contract Surgeons or
Acting Asst. Surgeons, the latter being their formal titles.

I am not sure whether you know it or not, but if you do
it will do no harm to repeat it. I have made a start on an article
bearing the tentative title of “Memoirs of a Human Guinea Pig”, the
main object of which will be to offset Cuban propaganda ALL-OUT-
FOR-FINLAY-WITH-NOTHING-FOR-REED. I have no intention of invading
the scientific field but to confine myself strictly to the layman's
point of view, based on facts and actual experience, making every
effort to stifle my well known sympathies for the master mind who
engineered and carried out the series of experiments which brought
fame and glory to REED and FINLAY. I had high hopes that Dr.
Hench would be the medium through which the scientific and the lay
world alike could learn the story, correctly and impartially. I
wanted to read his book while still in the land of the living. I
am encouraged by Paul de Kruif, a Reed-Finlay advocate but decidedly
pro-Carroll. He writes me that he will spend the winter in Havana
and will pass on the merits of my “Memoirs”. If the good Lord spares
me, I may be able to convert them into book size. Dr. Hench does
not have an exalted opinion of the author of “Microbe Hunters”, I am
sorry to state. Wishing you a Happy Birthday and with very kindest
regards from Elida and myself to Mrs. Kean and your very good self,
I remain
